title: Closing remarks

organizer: Geraint Wiggins, School of Electronic Engineering and Computer Science, Queen Mary, University of London
Amilcar Cardoso, Centre for Informatics and Systems (CISUC), University of Coimbra
Hannu Toivonen, Department of Computer Science, University of Helsinki

segmentation: OK, so it's time to close the school.
Here on screen I show again the spawn source.
So first of all the Prosecco network kindly funded.
Actually 45 of you.

Your participation and accommodation and meals here, so make sure thank you to the Prosecutor Network and then the Department of Computer Science at the University of Helsinki is to thank to a large extent to the Computational Creativity Club offerings.
And then of course, I'd like to thank the speakers.
Many of them were too busy to.
They already had to leave, but most are still here.
Thank you very much for an exciting program.
Thanks to all the students taking active part here, presenting posters, giving demos.
Especially the correct ones performing at the club.
Special thank you, especially thank you to Simon and Tony for keeping up with this custom here.
And what else?
The main tasks of the Prosecco network is to educate people on computational creativity, and I think we had a great success in this call here with 70 people attending the school for five days.
That's a major of thing.
Another important goal of the network is too.
Build up the community and I think we also managed to do that to a good extent, to the extent that actually there's been volunteers already setting up a group in Facebook.
There's been discussions about LinkedIn and so on.
Um so.

I'll be circulating an email next week, so if you have like, for instance, instructions for how to challenge the Facebook Group, please send it to me and I'll circulate a single email next week to all the participants on how to how to join this.
If you are interested who were here, the list of participants is available.

There with the names and affiliations I'm not giving out any more details for privacy reasons so, but here you can see who was who was there and then anybody who is interested in this Community Action is free to sign up to the groups on Facebook or elsewhere.
I have two slides.
The second one shows two important bodies in this field and I will next give of the word over to amilkar.
Oh here, right so few words about the Pro Seco Network and its future actions and then Association for computational creativity.
Presented by guarantee.
Well, I was suggesting a final applause for the organizers.
Actually, we could see in every details in all the details the big and the small details of this organization.
Examples real examples.
Instances of the seesaw concept.
So congratulations for your work.
Your end, the whole team of the Helsinki University.
Thank you.
Tony asked me to give you a few words about Prosecco, because he's not here anymore and there are three things I would like to talk about briefly.
One is that.
Prosecco, one of the goals of Prosecco, is as Hannah has said to build a community, and we have specific funds for moving people.
This means that if any of you is interested in visiting any of the partners, and you know the partners by looking at the site of the website, if you don't know them.
If you are interested in visiting any of them, you may send an email to the coordinator of the partner.
The coordinator person we do not guarantee that we will fund any travel, but maybe there is some possibility of doing it.
So if you are really interested just send an email to the person responsible for the node of Prosecco network.
OK, so do it.
Second thing, during the ICC conference in Ljubljana, Prosecco will be supporting two things.
One of them is a forum devoted to people from artistic fields that we want to attract to the area we want to them to join us.
Also, creative industries.
The exact details will be elaborated later.
So we will organize this forum which will be Co located with the conference.
I suppose it will not be a part of the conference but will happen at the same time or or so.
And also an art exhibit that Prosek will also be supporting.
So pay attention if you are an artist and want to contribute.
Pay attention to that.
Or music, any kind of art?
OK, third thing, besides schools, this is the first school supported by Pro SEQ.
There will be a second one in two years.
But besides schools besides the Forum forums that we will organize.
We also be we will.
We will also organize a code camp.
A code camp we expect to be very interesting event.
At least that's our intention to make it interesting.
The idea is to have people during Sunday's a bit like in here but coding.
And trying to exchange experiences, making facing challenges.
And first of all coding and trying to code for computational creativity.
There are not details yet about the exact place of it.
We are still dealing with that, but it will occur during the second year of the project.
That's to say during 2014 or the beginning of 15.
So pay attention to that because we want contributions from everybody to that.
OK, and that's all.
Thank you, Hannah again.

So, so I'm in a very strange position here of speaking for one organization while being part of another one, and I'm going to be the last person to start saying thank yous, so I'm chair of the Association for Computational Creativity, which is this thing here, which is a sort of international organization, or at least it's a non national organization.
It happens to be legally founded in as far as it's legally founded at all in the UK, but that's just because the UK has particularly light laws on.
Founding such things, especially, you just write down the fact that you've done it and you can.
So there is a steering committee that.
Is gently steering the development of computational through creativity as an international activity, most of which is done via the conference about which you've already heard.
I'm not going to repeat the lovely stories of Liliana that we can look forward to.
I do hope we will see lots of you there.
The more people are there, the more successful the conference will be for the people who are there.
So that will be a very good thing.
I think really all I need to say now is go forth and multiply.
Please tell your friends about what an exciting field this is, you know, and we hope that you will do really exciting things about it and in it, and with it.
That's what we're here for.
And I finally do want to add my thanks to on behalf of the Association for Computational Creativity.
Now to all of the speakers who put all of this effort in but really to handle and his team who have done an unbelievably good job.
You have no idea how much effort it is to organize an event like this, and as somebody I think amilkar already said, Cecil was evident in abundance there.
So thank you all so much.
It's you 2 an whoever else, Alessandro yes indeed, so thank you very much indeed and see you next time, or at least in Louisiana.
Better still.
